guides/guiding-methods/study-the-meaning.title: Study the meaning of the words
guides/guiding-methods/study-the-meaning.description:
Once we learn a language, we can use the words, the main building blocks of a sentence, effortlessly. But there is often much more to a word than what we know on the surface level.Human language is said to be 'messy' and ambiguous, context dependent, and not nearly as 'precise' as a formal language, like a programming language. The conversation with a friend, or this page will not crash if I make a semantic (meaning) or syntax (grammatical) error. Still, a lot can be learned by reading the dictionary entry of a word. A lot of words have their original roots in Latin and Greek.Studying these aspects of the words can provide new, useful insights, improve our mastery of them, etc.list the keywords
www.wordnik.com
guides/guiding-methods/study-the-meaning.sourcePath: guides/guiding methods/Study the meaning of the words.md

guides/guiding-methods.html.title: guiding methods
guides/guiding-methods.html.description:
method /ˈmɛθəd/ noun Origin: late Middle English (in the sense ‘prescribed medical treatment for a disease’): via Latin from Greek methodos ‘pursuit of knowledge’, from meta- (expressing development) + hodos ‘way’. Definitions: a particular procedure for accomplishing or approaching something, especially a systematic or established one. the quality of being well organized and systematic in thought or action Disclaimer: this 'list' will change massively as we go on, as the new things we learn and discover using these guiding methods will recursively change the process itself. The list here will have the TLDR version with more details in the full articles.As a first, self recursive guiding method let's have:
Keep in mind, check and develop the guiding methods you have We have used words, English words to articulate, note and document this first guiding principle. If the words make sense to you, good, it means we made an intelligible sentence. Words and writing are a very very powerful tool.
Inspect your base assumptions
We are not starting everything from 0, all the time. Whatever we do, whenever we communicate we make a number (innumerable) assumptions. This has an important function to keep things efficient, but there can be disadvantages, and in this case serious ones. But what exactly does the word, assumption mean?
Study the meaning of the words A lot can be learned by reading the dictionary entry of a word. The Contexts it is used in, it's Relateds, Synonyms, etc., it's Etymology (origin) can reveal new aspects and insights that will make thinking and documentation more effective and precise.
Make the methods actionable They are useful as text, but they will come alive as code. To keep in mind the guiding principles, methods, set up reminders and other mechanisms, make them as built in, integrated as possible.Of course this has to be elaborated much more to become robust. But let's start by defining some words that we have used so far.
index
welcome
guide
assume
assumption Acceptance: Accept that you don't know what this is, you do not know the shape of the 'problem' and maybe you never will Actionable: think about and implement things as code, action, etc. so they are not dead and static, but alive, dynamic and part of the stream and fabric of Life. Analysis, Elements: Keep track of that are the element, constituents of the systems at play, in use, and see what kinds of fields they generate. For example the words, sentences in text, the colors of an image, etc. Asimov: be as clear and precise as possible. It is not easy, and people underestimate this. Base Assumptions: take a step back, zoom out, be honest and try to articulate what your base assumptions are Change of Scenery, Environment Consilience: everything should be connected and the traversal should be natural Continuous Improvement Creative language, symbols: just like how locals and natives name different plants and animals based on some traits, so that the names themselves contain these traits, we should not be afraid to invent words, language to define specific Centers, Concepts in order to build new tools for thinking, and to avoid the confusion (conflation?) with existing concepts in the mental landscape/mindscape. Doubt, Question, Skepticism: it does not cost you anything to ask questions, have doubts and take skeptical positions. Environment: inspirational (books, things), comfort, relaxed?, lighting, which room, nature, peace, quiet, no possibility for interruption Guiding Principles: contemplate what foundations motivate you Holistic approach: not only the product is important but all aspects around it in all dimensions and directions (like this list itself) Itadakimasu: Japanese be thankful, grateful for the resources, food, energy you use, consume, which passes through you, keeps you alive Journey over Destination Kanban: Japanese Learn from History: at least learn that we don't learn from it! Lifecycle: everything has a lifecycle, so it is a common pattern that can help with analyzing, understanding, learning Meditation: calm, compose yourself, re-center Metaphors Mindset: should try to achieve, strive for the appropriate mindset that best first your current activity, creative, production, inspiration Mind your Balance Minimalism: be conservative with space and energy (for ease of maintenance, storage, access, complexity, utility) Mottainai: Japanese Multi-media, multi-view: why not provide all functions, views, representations for everything? Natural abilities: Tap into the natural abilities of the Person Nutrition: use different states of nutrition (hunger and fasting are not bad) Organization: better organized, for easier access, manipulation, transformation, communication, storage, backup Origin: study the origin and etymology of things, words, names, concepts, people, etc. Pattern Break: Mix it up sometimes Preservation: constant backup, preservation, conservation **Pros and Cons Random: take a chance sometimes Review: the relation of everything to everything Rewatch, re-read, etc. periodically, you might learn, find something new, see things in a new, different, better light Save for later: Keep things that you do not understand yet, but feel, have an intuition that will be important or valuable, and might come back to in the future Stepwise elaboration, levels of scale: all representations should be gradual, zooming in-out should be natural (like this point itself) Subconscious: let your mind work on it in the background while you use your consciousness, focus and attention for more immediate matters Switch points of view, perspectives: try as many as you can, contemplate and compare them, understand the differences Try different structures: cyclical, linear, tree, branching, networked Unfolding: everything should be foldable stepwise, in a natural beautiful way (like Origami), from one point, to complete multidimensional, explorable space Use Colors Use Language Use your circumstances: lean into your gifts, abilities, genetics, knowledge, power, wealth, etc. Version control: know where you left off, see the evolution, try forks Video, Text, Transcript, Audio, Presentation, etc.

guides/guiding-principles.html.title: guiding principles
guides/guiding-principles.html.description: principle /ˈprɪn(t)sɪpl/ late Middle English: from Old French, from Latin principium ‘source’, principia (plural) ‘foundations’, from princeps, princip- ‘first, chief’. a rule or belief governing one's behaviour. morally correct behaviour and attitudes. a fundamental truth or proposition that serves as the foundation for a system of belief or behaviour or for a chain of reasoning. a fundamental source or basis of something. a fundamental quality determining the nature of something. A guiding principle is a fundamental, core belief or value that directs an individual's or organization's decisions, behaviors, and actions. These principles serve as an internal compass, providing a framework for consistency, ethics, and strategic direction regardless of changing circumstances. Behind every action, activity, there seems to be a guiding principle, process, a source, even if we don't realize or cannot articulate them. But being aware can provide a powerful framework.

guides/inspirations.html.title: inspirations
guides/inspirations.html.description:
inspiration /ɪnspɪˈreɪʃ(ə)n/ Origin: Middle English (in the sense ‘divine guidance’): via Old French from late Latin inspiratio(n- ), from the verb inspirare (see inspire). Definitions: the process of being mentally stimulated to do or feel something, especially to do something creative. the quality of being inspired. a sudden brilliant or timely idea. the drawing in of breath; inhalation. Without providing any specific context at the moment, here are some things I consider inspirational. Nature Cosmos Flowers Beauty Common Sense Systems Theory Gaia Rhizome Structure Preserving Transformations Pattern Theory 15 Properties (of space) Gestalt Christopher Alexander Isaac Asimov Jonathan Blow (Jon Blow) Brian Moriarty Stanislaw Lem Jeremy England Alan Watts
Albert Einstein - https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Albert_Einstein
Bret Victor - https://worrydream.com/
https://dynamicland.org/
Christopher Alexander: Patterns in Architecture (1996) - youtube, transcript Jonathan Blow
Video Games and the Human Condition (2010) - youtube
Preventing the Collapse of Civilization (2019) - youtube Alexander Rose: The Data of Long-Lived Institutions — Alexander Rose at The Interval Bret Victor
Drawing Dynamic Visualizations (2015) - youtube - vimeo - Victor's Notes
Media for Thinking the Unthinkable (April, 2013) - link
The Humane Representation of Thought - home - youtube - vimeo Alan Watts: Do You Do It or Does It Do You? Christopher Alexander Notes on the Synthesis of Form A Pattern Language The Nature of Order: An Essay on the Art of Building and the Nature of the Universe The Phenomenon of Life The Process of Creating Life A Vision of a Living World The Luminous Ground Keith Houston The BOOK Robert Pirsig Zen and the Art of Motorcycle Maintenance Tao Te Ching Italo Calvino Invisible Cities Isaac Asimov Foundation Tetris Braid (2008) The Witness (2016) Outer Wilds (2019) Sekiro: Shadows Die Twice (2019) Elden Ring (2022)

questions/how-do-we-learn？.html.title: How do we learn？
questions/how-do-we-learn？.html.description:
Dictionary learn /ləːn/ become aware of (something) by information or from observation. To fix in the mind or memory; memorize. To become aware or informed of; find out: synonym: discover. To gain knowledge of or skill in through study, instruction, or experience. Keywords awareness information observation mind memory memorize discover knowledge skill study school instruction experience teach
intelligence method: list the keywords Core Beliefs learning is the way for the Universe to get to know itself this is one of the most fundamental questions for us, humans Metaphors Training The definitions listed in the Dictionary are a good staring point, they are the tip of the proverbial Iceberg and only scratch the surface.The word learn, abstraction it represents, and the strong societal associations with it make it a bit more difficult to see through or underneath clearly. What growth and training is to the body, learning is to the mind? What is learning? Why do we learn? How easy is it for knowledge to spread? How easy is it to learn? How does information reach us? Environment Intelligence Knowledge Note-taking Practice Training Memory Memorization
method: list associations The Witness James Burke videolog James Burke - Connections: How easy is it for knowledge to spread School observation books reading test mistake proof pleasure discovery power Environment intelligence What training is to the body, learning is to the mind?

words/aspire.html.title: aspire
words/aspire.html.description:
/əˈspʌɪə/late Middle English: from French aspirer or Latin aspirare, from ad- ‘to’ + spirare ‘breathe’.
verb direct one's hopes or ambitions towards achieving something.
rise high; tower.
To have a great ambition or ultimate goal; desire strongly.
To strive toward an end or condition.
Archaic To rise high; move upwards.
To breathe to or into.

words/assume.html.title: assume
words/assume.html.description:
/əˈsjuːm/late Middle English: from Latin assumere, from ad- ‘towards’ + sumere ‘take’.
verb suppose to be the case, without proof.
take or begin to have (power or responsibility).
begin to have (a specified quality, appearance, or extent).
take on or adopt (a manner or identity), sometimes falsely. Middle English assumen, from Latin assūmere : ad-, ad- + sūmere, to take; see em- in Indo-European roots.From Latin assūmō ("accept, take"), from ad- ("to, towards, at") + sūmō ("take up, assume").

words/assumption.html.title: assumption
words/assumption.html.description: /əˈsʌm(p)ʃn/From Middle English assumpcioun, from Medieval Latin assumptio ("a taking up (into heaven)") and Latin assumption ("a taking up, adoption, the minor proposition of a syllogism"); see assume. noun a thing that is accepted as true or as certain to happen, without proof. the action of taking on power or responsibility. verb Middle English assumpcion, from Latin assūmptiō__, assūmptiōn-, adoption, from assūmptus, past participle of assūmere, to adopt; see assume.Middle English (in assumption(sense 3 of the noun)): from Old French asompsion or Latin assumptio(n- ), from the verb assumere (see assume)

words/erudition.html.title: erudition
words/erudition.html.description:
noun Deep, extensive learning. synonym: knowledge.
Learning; scholarship; knowledge gained by study or from books and instruction; particularly, learning in literature, history, antiquities, and languages, as distinct from knowledge of the mathematical and physical sciences.
The act of instructing; the result of thorough instruction; the state of being erudite or learned; the acquisitions gained by extensive reading or study; particularly, learning in literature or criticism, as distinct from the sciences; scholarship.
Profound knowledge, especially that based on learning and scholarship. From Latin eruditio ("an instructing, learning, erudition"), from erudire ("to instruct, educate, cultivate", literally "free from rudeness"), from e ("out") + rudis ("rude").The word "erudition" comes from the Latin eruditio, meaning "learning," which is a noun from the verb erudire, meaning "to instruct" or "to educate". This Latin verb is a compound of e- ("out") and rudis ("rude," "unskilled," or "rough"), so erudire literally meant "to free from rudeness". Therefore, erudition is the result of being "taken out of a rough or uncultivated state" through a process of education and learning. 
Latin roots: erudire = e- ("out") + rudis ("rough," "unskilled").
Literal meaning: "To free from rudeness" or "to remove coarseness".
Figurative meaning: The process of educating or instructing someone, leading them from a state of being "rough" or unlearned to one of polished and extensive knowledge.
Modern usage: The noun "erudition" refers to the deep, scholarly knowledge that results from this process.

words/garden.html.title: garden
words/garden.html.description: /ˈɡɑːdn/Middle English: from Old Northern French gardin, variant of Old French jardin, of Germanic origin; related to yard2. cultivate or work in a garden. a piece of ground adjoining a house, in which grass, flowers, and shrubs may be grown. ornamental grounds laid out for public enjoyment and recreation. a large public hall.

words/guide.html.title: guide
words/guide.html.description:
/ɡʌɪd/late Middle English: from Old French guide (noun), guider (verb), of Germanic origin; related to wit2. verb show or indicate the way to (someone). direct the motion or positioning of (something). Noun One who shows the way by leading, directing, or advising. One who serves as a model for others, as in a course of conduct.
https://wordnik.com/words/guide

words/index.html.title: index
words/index.html.description:
/ˈɪndɛks/late Middle English: from Latin index, indic- ‘forefinger, informer, sign’, from in- ‘towards’ + a second element related to dicere ‘say’ or dicare ‘make known’; compare with indicate. The original sense ‘index finger’ (with which one points), came to mean ‘pointer’ (late 16th century), and figuratively something that serves to point to a fact or conclusion; hence a list of topics in a book (‘pointing’ to their location).
noun Something that serves to guide, point out, or otherwise facilitate reference, especially.
An alphabetized list of names, places, and subjects treated in a printed work, giving the page or pages on which each item is mentioned. Middle English, forefinger, from Latin; see deik- in Indo-European roots.From Latin index ("a discoverer, informer, spy; of things, an indicator, the forefinger, a title, superscription"), from indicō ("point out, show"); see indicate.

words/inspiration.html.title: inspiration
words/inspiration.html.description:
/ɪnspɪˈreɪʃ(ə)n/Origin: Middle English (in the sense ‘divine guidance’): via Old French from late Latin inspiratio(n- ), from the verb inspirare (see inspire).Definitions:
the process of being mentally stimulated to do or feel something, especially to do something creative.
the quality of being inspired.
a sudden brilliant or timely idea.
the drawing in of breath; inhalation.
Similar words:
creativity
inventiveness
innovation
imagination
stimulus
motivation
inhalation
revelation
brainwave

words/method.html.title: method
words/method.html.description:
/ˈmɛθəd/ late Middle English (in the sense ‘prescribed medical treatment for a disease’): via Latin from Greek methodos ‘pursuit of knowledge’, from meta- (expressing development) + hodos ‘way’.Definitions:
a particular procedure for accomplishing or approaching something, especially a systematic or established one.
the quality of being well organized and systematic in thought or action

words/page.html.title: page
words/page.html.description:
/peɪdʒ/late 15th century: from French, from Latin pagina, from pangere ‘fasten’.Definitions:
verb look through the pages of (a book, magazine, etc.).
Computing move through and display (text) one page at a time.
divide (a piece of software or data) into sections, keeping the most frequently accessed in main memory and storing the rest in virtual memory. Noun the material written or printed on a page.
a page of a newspaper or magazine set aside for a particular topic.
Computing a section of stored data, especially that which can be displayed on a screen at one time. a significant event or period considered as a part of a longer history. Similar:
folio
sheet
side
leaf
period
stage
phase

words/principle.html.title: principle
words/principle.html.description:
/ˈprɪn(t)sɪpl/late Middle English: from Old French, from Latin principium ‘source’, principia (plural) ‘foundations’, from princeps, princip- ‘first, chief’.Definitions:
a rule or belief governing one's behaviour.
morally correct behaviour and attitudes.
a fundamental truth or proposition that serves as the foundation for a system of belief or behaviour or for a chain of reasoning.
a fundamental source or basis of something. a fundamental quality determining the nature of something.

words/site.html.title: site
words/site.html.description:
/sʌɪt/late Middle English (as a noun): from Anglo-Norman French, or from Latin situs ‘local position’. The verb dates from the late 16th century.Definitions:
verb fix or build (something) in a particular place. Noun an area of ground on which a town, building, or monument is constructed.
a place where a particular event or activity is occurring or has occurred.
short for 'building site'.
short for campsite or caravan site.
a website.

words/welcome.html.title: welcome
words/welcome.html.description:
/ˈwɛlkəm/
adjective Received with pleasure and hospitality into one's company or home.
Giving pleasure or satisfaction; agreeable or gratifying. noun A cordial greeting or hospitable reception given to an arriving person.
A reception upon arrival.
The state of being welcome. verb To greet, receive, or entertain (another or others) cordially or hospitably. interjection Used to greet cordially a visitor or recent arrival. Old English wilcuma ‘a person whose coming is pleasing’, wilcumian (verb), from wil- ‘desire, pleasure’ + cuman ‘come’. The first element was later changed to wel- ‘well’, influenced by Old French bien venu or Old Norse velkominn .Middle English, alteration (influenced by wel, well) of Old English wilcuma, welcome guest, welcome; see gwā- in Indo-European roots.

words/word.html.title: word
words/word.html.description:
/wəːd/Old English word, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch woord and German Wort, from an Indo-European root shared by Latin verbum ‘word’.Definitions:
verb express (something spoken or written) in particular words. Noun a command, password, or signal.
something spoken or written; a remark or statement.
even the smallest amount of something spoken or written.
one's account of the truth, especially when it differs from that of another person.
a basic unit of data in a computer, typically 16 or 32 bits long.

aspirations.html.description:
aspire /əˈspʌɪə/ late Middle English: from French aspirer or Latin aspirare, from ad- ‘to’ + spirare ‘breathe’. direct one's hopes or ambitions towards achieving something. rise high; tower.
Some of my aspirations are listed on the welcome page, enough for now...
humane learning

digital-garden.html.title: digital garden
digital-garden.html.description:
garden
/ˈɡɑːdn/ Middle English: from Old Northern French gardin, variant of Old French jardin, of Germanic origin; related to yard2. cultivate or work in a garden. a piece of ground adjoining a house, in which grass, flowers, and shrubs may be grown. ornamental grounds laid out for public enjoyment and recreation. a large public hall. I decided to try this form of publishing as it aligns the most with my way of thinking (at the moment).It's purpose is to use it as a means of documenting, publishing (sharing) my thinking about a couple of initiatives I am trying to realize.I hope it will help to force me to think very carefully about the ideas I am trying to develop, about the words I use, and the thoughts I publish.
https://maggieappleton.com/garden-history - Maggie Appleton's wonderful A Brief History & Ethos of the Digital Garden.
https://www.eastgate.com/garden/Enter.html - One of the early Hypertext Gardens.

guide

welcome.html.title: welcome
welcome.html.description:
welcome /ˈwɛlkəm/ Old English wilcuma ‘a person whose coming is pleasing’, wilcumian (verb), from wil- ‘desire, pleasure’ + cuman ‘come’. The first element was later changed to wel- ‘well’, influenced by Old French bien venu or Old Norse velkominn . Received with pleasure and hospitality into one's company or home. The state of being welcome.
Welcome to my mind garden (mind mapping, 2nd brain, etc.) experiment. It is in the form of a digital garden.Disclaimer: Let me emphasize, this is an experiment both in it's form and content. While this format has it's advantages at the moment, I really wish there were better, more humane ways for expressing such intellectual experiences. Creating such a new medium is among my dreams.
Some of my aspirations: philosophical
understanding The Universe (Reality, The World, whatever you wanna call it), because I am in awe at the phenomenon of existence, life, consciousness and want to feel at home and be fully connected both 'intellectually' and 'spiritually' making improvements and leaving The World a better place (one where I'd like to be constantly re-born) practical finding ways to practically apply Christopher Alexander's theories found in The Nature of Order, into everyday life Living Structure 15 Properties Structure Preserving Transformations because I believe these ways of seeing the World are more correct, and will supersede the current, predominantly mechanistic worldview realizing The Glass Bead Game (described in Hermann Hesse's book of the same name), because in my interpretation, conception, it would be one of the highest forms of Communication, Understanding, Art and honestly it would be a super fun to experience. I believe there may be People who suffer, because this instrument has not yet been created and therefore cannot express themselves to the highest degree (just imagine, if the piano was not there in the time of Mozart)
participating in projects that help make learning, computing and thinking tools more humane becoming fluent in Japanese ...
Some of my beliefs (I guess my base assumptions, in a way): When I read Christopher Alexander's The Nature of Order, I had a worldview shift, and since then I completely ascribe to the view, that every part of space has a degree of Life (as opposed to segregating 'living' and 'dead' things) and Wholeness (aka. Health) and that it is our duty and responsibility to learn how this structure emerges in Nature so that we can be an extension of Structure Preserving Process, the Structure Enhancing Process. I believe the process of Nature is to create Beauty and the accompanying Consciousness to experience it. Learning is the process that 'facilitates' this. It is the way for Nature to Sense itself. Does it make sense?
Some questions I ask myself (very high level):
How do we learn？ How does information reach us? How are we informed? How are we outformed? What is the theory of Note-taking? What is the Nature of the Universe?
Now that we put some aspirations into words, what will be our guides?
inspirations (divine guidance)
guiding principles
guiding methods

info_defaultMediaIcon.description: The icon to use for media files. Prefix with 'lucide//' to use a Lucide icon

info_showOrphanNodes.description: Show nodes that are not connected to any other nodes.

info_showAttachments.description: Show attachments like images and PDFs as nodes in the graph.

info_allowGlobalGraph.description: Allow the user to view the global graph of all nodes.

info_allowExpand.description: Allow the user to pop-out the graph view to take up the whole screen

info_attractionForce.description: How much should linked nodes attract each other? This will make the graph appear more clustered.

info_linkLength.description: How long should the links between nodes be? The shorter the links the more connected nodes will cluster together.

info_repulsionForce.description: How much should nodes repel each other? This will make disconnected parts more spread out.

info_centralForce.description: How much should nodes be attracted to the center? This will make the graph appear more dense and circular.

info_edgePruning.description: Edges with a length above this threshold will not be rendered, however they will still contribute to the simulation. This can help large tangled graphs look more organised. Hovering over a node will still display these links.

info_minNodeRadius.description: How small should the smallest nodes be? The smaller a node is the less it will attract other nodes.

info_maxNodeRadius.description: How large should the largest nodes be? Nodes are sized by how many links they have. The larger a node is the more it will attract other nodes. This can be used to create a good grouping around the most important nodes.

info_allowResizing.description: Whether or not to allow the sidebars to be resized

info_allowCollapsing.description: Whether or not to allow the sidebars to be collapsed

info_rightDefaultWidth.description: The default width of the right sidebar

info_leftDefaultWidth.description: The default width of the left sidebar

info_selector.description: CSS selector for an element. The feature will be placed relative to this element.

info_type.description: Will this feature be placed before, after, or inside (at the beggining or end).

info_featurePlacement.description: Where to place this feature on the page. (Relative to the selector)

info_sourcePath.description: The local path to the source .html file which will be included.

info_allowFoldingLists.description: Whether or not to allow lists to be folded

info_allowFoldingHeadings.description: Whether or not to allow headings to be folded

info_siteUrl.description: The url that this site will be hosted at

info_authorName.description: The name of the author of the site

bodyClasses: publish css-settings-manager mod-windows is-frameless is-hidden-frameless styled-scrollbars show-inline-title show-ribbon show-view-header is-focused
